elements.content: On the basis of acid−pyridine and acid−amide hydrogen bond synthons in dicarboxylic acid−isonicotinamide complexes and proton/silver mimicry in carboxylic acids, isonicotinamide was reacted with AgBF4 to afford different coordination compounds. The crystal structure of [Ag(C5H4NCONH2)2][BF4] 1 has linear tapes of Npyridyl−Ag−Npyridyl (180.0°) connected via N−H···O and N−H···F hydrogen bonds in square nets with CdSO4 topology. The 16 × 17 Å voids eschew 5-fold interpenetration of identical nets. [Ag(C5H4NCONH2)][BF4] 2 provides the first occurrence of near linear Npyridyl−Ag−Oamide bonds (165.4°). The similarity in motifs of carboxylic acid and Ag(I) is extended to heterosynthons for crystal engineering.

elements.content: Isonicotinamide is a versatile reagent in crystal engineering for the synthesis of binary crystals with hydrogen bond donor groups (carboxylic acid, phenol) and coordination compounds with silver salts (AgBF4, AgPF6, AgO3SCF3). The body of structural data suggests that the donor H-atom of COOH and soft metal Ag(I) preferentially bond with the pyridine moiety of isonicotinamide (or nicotinamide); bonding with amide carbonyl oxygen is considered to be unlikely. We noted in a recent study of α,ω-dicarboxylic acid-isonicotinamide cocrystals that linear tapes of acid···pyridine I and acid···amide II synthons are present in 1:1 adducts with glutaric acid and adipic acid; 1:2 diacid-isonicotinamide cocrystals contain acid···pyridine synthon I and amide···amide dimer III (Scheme ). Brammer has shown that Ag(I) behaves like a “large proton” in its bonding ability with carboxylate and has drawn a parallel between carboxylic acid dimer IV and Ag-mediated synthons V and VI. In this background, we reasoned whether coordination bonding of Ag(I) with isonicotinamide would lead to motifs VII and VIII in analogy with carboxylic acid synthons I and II (Scheme ). Isolation of 1:1 Ag(I)-isonicotinamide with motif VIII will provide the first example of (pyridine)N−Ag−O(amide) linkage in coordination polymers or organic−inorganic hybrid structures. Motif VIII is not mentioned in a recent comprehensive review on this topic. The Cambridge Structural Database (July 2003 update, 296 427 entries) has 27 crystal structures with Ag, pyridine, and amide fragments but no structure has motif VIII; synthon VII is present in 13 structures.

elements.content: Dissolution of AgBF4 and isonicotinamide in dry EtOH by gentle warming afforded crystals of needle and plate morphology at room temperature within a week. Examination of a few crystals from the same flask showed that they belong to the triclinic P1̄ and monoclinic P21/c space group. We report in this paper the X-ray crystal structure of [Ag(C5H4NCONH2)2][BF4] 1 and [Ag(C5H4NCONH2)][BF4] 2 stabilized by N−Ag−N and N−Ag−O coordination bonds together with N−H···O and N−H···F hydrogen bonds. When AgBF4 and isonicotinamide were dissolved in moist EtOH crystals of [Ag(C5H4NCONH2)3][BF4]2b,7 3 were characterized by X-ray diffraction. We observed over several experiments that the product composition depends on the choice of solvent conditions (dry vs wet EtOH) and not so much on the ratio of components mixed (1:1 to 1:3). Using a slight excess of ligand (1:3) gave 1 and 2 reproducibly from analytical grade EtOH, while 3 was obtained from wet EtOH.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 (P1̄) contains two symmetry independent isonicotinamide molecules (IN1 and IN2), two Ag(I) atoms (Ag1 and Ag2) with 0.5 occupancy each and one ion of BF4 -. Ag1−IN1 forms a linear tape of silver−pyridine coordination bond (2.13 Å, synthon VII) and amide N−H···O dimer (1.89 Å, 169.7°). In the crystallographically independent zigzag chain of Ag2−IN2 molecules (Ag−N 2.13 Å, synthon VII), amide dimer III is absent on the other side. Instead, BF4 - ions connect CONH2 groups via centrosymmetric N−H···F motif IX (2.02 Å, 168.3°; 1.93 Å, 153.3°). It is notable that the N−Ag−N angle is 180.0° in both symmetry-independent molecules. IX is a novel motif in the sub-database of 27 crystal structures, whereas seven occurrences of amide dimer III are present. Symmetry-independent chains are connected by N−H···F and C−H···F hydrogen bonds (1.95 Å, 158.7°; 2.32 Å, 161.8°) in a bifurcated motif via the BF4 - counterion, as shown in Figure a. In effect, BF4 - is intimately involved in the hydrogen bond network of 1, with three F atoms engaged in N−H···F or C−H···F hydrogen bonding. Inversion- related IN1 molecules are π-stacked at center-to-center distance of 3.54 Å. There are long Ag···O and Ag···F contacts (2.9−3.0 Å), but they are more in the nature of weak noncovalent interactions. The packing of symmetry-independent chains of molecules, oriented at an angle of 73° (N1−F3−N3−O2 torsion angle) and connected via N−H···F H-bond, is topologically identical to tetragonal CdSO4 network if the centers of synthons III and IX are approximated as square nodes (Figure b). The 16 × 17 Å voids are filled by 5-fold interpenetration of identical networks (Figure c), the highest order of catenation in CdSO4 nets. Five-fold interpenetrated frame with CdSO4 topology is reported10a in the crystal structure of [Cu(bpe)2(SO4)]·5H2O (bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane), but this is true only if part of the intricate structure is considered by removing one of the symmetry-independent bpe molecules. The crystal structure of 3 has been described as 2-fold interpenetrated α-ThSi2 net.

elements.content: During the writing of this manuscript we noted that the term “Lincoln log” is used in the literature to describe two distinct 3D networks. Whitesides and co-workers12a have described the mesoscale assembly of polyurethane rods in which adjacent rods lie at right angles to each other as Lincoln log. This orthogonal stacking of 4-connected square rods is identical to the CdSO4 network. On the other hand, Moulton and Zaworotko12b have referred to the 3-connected network in [Ag(4,4‘-bipyridine)][NO3], such that parallel strips of T-shaped metal centers in alternate layers are arranged with half offset, as Lincoln log. The latter arrangement is topologically identical to the ThSi2 network. The confusion in usage of Lincoln log terminology for different networks is not totally surprising because different arrangements of logs, corresponding to these 3D nets, have been described as Lincoln log in the construction of wood cabins and Lego building-blocks (see Supplementary Information for schematic representation of 3D networks and Lincoln log cabins). In light of the increasing number of network structures being reported regularly, we suggest that 3D nets be named by their inorganic structure equivalents to avoid ambiguity.

elements.content: In 1:1 compound 2 (P21/c), Ag(I) forms coordination bonds with pyridine N and amide O acceptors (Ag−N 2.18 Å, Ag−O 2.20 Å, N−Ag−O 165.4°, C−O−Ag 130.7°, motif VIII) to produce a linear coordination polymer along the c-axis. Inversion-related chains are held by Ag···O and weak Ag···Ag interactions (2.62 Å, 3.61 Å). The CONH2 is bonded to different BF4 - ions that in turn connect to glide-related chains through N−H···F and C−H···F hydrogen bonds (1.87 Å, 166.7°; 2.00 Å, 171.6°; 2.26 Å, 132.4°, Figure ). Corrugated layers constituted of Ag+−IN and BF4 - are parallel to the bc-plane and stack along the a-axis via C−H···F interaction (2.42 Å, 136.7°). The 1:1 Ag-isonicotinamide polymer 2 is therefore isolated in analogy with the dicarboxylic acid−isonicotinamide 1:1 cocrystal. Moreover, 2 is the first structure with N−Ag−O covalent bonds in near linear array VIII, in contrast to six structures in the CSD with long, bent motif. Although the N−Ag−N bond linkage is well-known in [Ag(nicotinamide)2][BF4] and [Ag(isonicotinamide)3][BF4], structure 2 provides a rare example of Ag bonding with amide oxygen and pyridine nitrogen. In comparison, silver(I)-pyridylurea compounds contain a Ag−N bond (synthon VII) even though the carbonyl oxygen of urea is a stronger Lewis base than amide CO.

elements.content: The isolation of 1 and 2 with motifs VII and VIII may be compared with the closely related structure of silver-isonicotinate in which N−Ag−N and N−Ag−O- aggregates are present as symmetry-independent molecules in the same crystal. These results suggest that the energy of coordination compounds 1 and 2 isolated from the same flask under identical crystal growth conditions must be very close. Structural isomers from the same flask and crystal structures of coordination compounds with different metal-to-ligand ratio continue to interest crystal engineers.

elements.content: In summary, we expand the mimicry of proton and silver from synthons V, VI in complexes with monofunctional nitrogen bases4 to motifs VII and VIII in coordination compounds with multifunctional ligand. Studies are ongoing with different counterions, ligands, and solvent conditions to develop further a unified theme of organic and inorganic crystal engineering.
